item.title: Paris Museums and Nightclubs Show Signs of Recovery After Attacks
item.description: Public campaigns and promotions have helped lift attendance at museums, theaters and nightclubs after the slump caused by the Nov. 13 attacks.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Chinese Stock Plunge Forces a Trading Halt, and Global Markets Shudder
item.description: Stocks in the U.S. and Europe sank after the Chinese central bank lowered the reference rate for the renminbi to its lowest point in almost six years.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and AMIE TSANG
item.media:description: An investor as an electronic board halted the display of stock market data at a securities brokerage house in Beijing.

item.title: Iran Accuses Saudi Arabia of Attacking Embassy in Yemen
item.description: Saudi officials said the airstrikes targeted missile launchers that Houthi rebels have used to fire across the border into the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: People gathered at the site of Saudi-led airstrikes in Sana, Yemen, on Wednesday.

item.title: Bacterium in Ötzi the Iceman’s Stomach Offers Clue on Human Migration
item.description: An insight into the peopling of Europe has emerged from an unlikely source — the stomach contents of a 5,300-year-old body pulled from a thawing glacier.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS WADE
item.media:description: Scientists studied a bacterium found in the stomach of the mummified man nicknamed Ötzi the Iceman, seen here in a photograph released by the University of Camerino, in Italy, in 2008.

item.title: Syria Agrees to Food Aid for Starving Rebel-Held Town, U.N. Says
item.description: With no firm date for deliveries to begin to Madaya, however, tens of thousands of people remain at risk, United Nationals officials warned.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Poland’s President Approves Controls on State Media, Alarming E.U. Leaders
item.description: The legislation will allow Poland’s new conservative government to appoint and dismiss the executives in charge of public television and radio broadcasters.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Letter From Europe: In Britain, Shadows of Past Military Tactics Loom Large
item.description: An ISIS video warns that Britain will lose in Syria “as you lost in Iraq and Afghanistan,” and reports of abuse by British troops in Iraq are growing.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Joao Silva for The New York Times
item.media:description: British soldiers taking cover as a helicopter left a base in Sangin, Afghanistan, in 2007.

item.title: Man With Knife and Fake Explosives Shot Dead Outside Paris Police Station
item.description: The attack, around noon, prompted the closing of schools, shops and streets, and the man’s body lay on the street outside the station on the Rue de la Goutte d’Or.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and ANNA POLONYI
item.media:description: An officer inspecting the body of a man shot dead outside a police station in northern Paris on Thursday.

item.title: Muslim Brotherhood Supporters Clash With Security Forces Outside Cairo Hotel
item.description: The Egyptian government attributed the violence to political unrest and said that tourists had not been directly targeted.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A woman cleaned smashed glass off a hotel's facade in Cairo on Thursday.

item.title: In the Birthplace of Pizza, Pollution Rules for Ovens Spur Outrage
item.description: The mayor of San Vitaliano, Italy, is taking heat from local pizzeria owners over a new law requiring filters on wood-fired stoves to curb emissions.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gennaro Marano preparing a pizza on Monday at Il Cavallino, a restaurant in San Vitaliano, Italy. In an effort to decrease air pollution, the mayor of the town, Antonio Falcone, issued an ordinance banning the use of wood-fired stoves not equipped with proper filters.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: A Cultural Revolution in Malaysia
item.description: Leveraging ancient trading links, China is fostering closer ties through pop music.
item.dc:creator: TASH AW

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Chen Tao, Who Runs ‘Star Wars’ Site, on Film’s Impact in China
item.description: Mr. Tao, who manages China’s biggest website for fans of “Star Wars,” discussed the movie’s fan base and how he became addicted to the Force.
item.dc:creator: CAO LI
item.media:description: Chen Tao, who oversees China's leading website for “Star Wars” fans, with a stormtrooper, in Shanghai in 2011.

item.title: Many in Hong Kong Fear Beijing’s Reach After Editor’s Disappearance
item.description: The disappearance of five people tied to a publishing house in Hong Kong is an example of the lengthening arm of Beijing, legal scholars and rights groups say.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Protesters with photographs of five missing booksellers, including Lee Bo, second from right, this week.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Attacks Libyan Training Camp, Killing at Least 40
item.description: There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing in the western coastal town of Zlitan, one of the deadliest in the country in recent memory.
item.dc:creator: SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: South Korea to Resume Propaganda Broadcasts That Angered North
item.description: The use of border loudspeakers that infuriated Pyongyang last summer is a response to the North’s latest nuclear test.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Donald Trump Says He’ll Pull Scotland Investment if Britain Bars Him
item.description: After his comments on Muslims, interest surged in a petition calling for Mr. Trump to not be allowed to enter the country on the basis of laws against hate speech.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Ramadi Grapples With Scars of War After Its Return to Iraqi Hands
item.description: The city’s retaking has been hailed, but its destruction bears testament to the cost of dislodging a group that stitches itself into the fabric of the communities it seizes.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: The retaking of Ramadi by Iraqi security forces last week has been hailed as a major blow to the Islamic State.

item.title: Guatemala Arrests Former Military Officers in Connection With Massacres
item.description: The authorities arrested 18 former officers on charges related to massacres and disappearances in the 1980s, the bloodiest period of the country’s 36-year civil war.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Oil Storage Tanks Burn After ISIS Attacks Ports
item.description: A spokesman for the Petroleum Facilities Guards said at least nine guards and 30 militants had been killed.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Defective Life Jackets Seized at Workshop
item.description: The Turkish authorities seized more than 1,200 jackets that would have been sold to migrants and that were made of material that did not float.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
